You have confirmation bias without even realizing it. The truth is really just an extension of that native bias you hold. It’s how those on the political aisle align themselves. When the opinion is something that floats in the air, aimlessly, it won’t matter. It isn’t the truth because it sounds stupid—and it’s stupid because nobody believes it to be true. When you believe that opinion, then it is true to you. When many people believe it, then that is seen as the truth. Ask yourself how many times you bait the answer to a question you are searching for on Google and you’ll understand how crazy that is. You’ll always look for things to add to your own framework of what you believe are correct opinions. This works in pretty much anything. The stock market, for instance, is just a widely accepted cacophony of people believing certain things are extremely valuable (the truth). When that opinion begins to change with the larger holders of stock, the stock begins to die off or deflate significantly. If you want to challenge when something becomes truth even further, listen to those you would consider most radical to yourself. Actually listen to what they are saying, look up the things they are talking about—try to understand that narrative and how it forms and where it is developed from. There is no greater truth than the one formed out of independent thought.
